pr_title: refactor(iot-dev, e2e): Fix log statement, add throttle resiliency to tests

timeline.message:
refactor(iot-dev, e2e): Fix log statement, add throttle resiliancy to tests

Also add bulk add functionality to e2e tests to help with upcoming multiplexing tests

timeline.bodyText: return gson.toJson(exportImportDevices) in a single line ?
timeline.author: vinagesh

timeline.bodyText: minor: "the json string used to build the ExportImportDevicesParser" might sound better.
timeline.author: vinagesh

timeline.bodyText: minor: This could be moved below line 51
timeline.author: vinagesh

timeline.bodyText: Does final mean we can only set this value once in the constructor? Trying to understand how java works.
timeline.author: vinagesh

replies.bodyText: The final modifier simply means that the method cannot be overriden by any class that extends this class. You can set/get this value as many times as you'd like, and whenever you'd like
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.author: vinagesh

timeline.bodyText: Should this be if or while? Are we not adding only one to the list or am I missing something?
timeline.author: vinagesh

replies.bodyText: This if block represents what should happen once a list of 100 devices is ready to be added, or if a list of under 100 devices is ready to add and there are no more devices to add after this list
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

replies.bodyText: The purpose here is so that this method can take a list of arbitrary length, and chunk that list into smaller lists of 100 devices or fewer so that we can use the bulk add service API which has a limit of 100 devices per request
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: Why is this declared outside of the try/catch?
timeline.author: drwill-ms

timeline.bodyText: comparison seems numerically backwards (checking the large number before the small number), but maybe that's just me
timeline.author: drwill-ms

replies.bodyText: I'm not sure I follow which half of the if statement you mean here
replies.author: timtay-microsoft

timeline.bodyText: Well that is something interesting that Java can do
timeline.author: drwill-ms

timeline.bodyText: I only see 2 instances of {}, but 3 parameters. Is the exception parameter a special one?
timeline.author: drwill-ms

replies.bodyText: The exception parameter is indeed special here. The log.warn (and log.error) will handle this exception without needing a {}
replies.author: timtay-microsoft
